class_notes:
This junior-senior colloquium takes a multidisciplinary approach to music and politics. We will look at many genres, from pop music around the world, to music of protest & resistance, to classical music & opera. The music industry, too, will interest us, such as the marketing of artists & genres. We will look at artists like Beyonc√©, international genres like KPop, American jazz in Berlin, Latin American protest songs, problematic forms like minstrel shows, and at least one lesbian heroine in Italian opera, and Mozart's Marriage of Figaro. Students can choose a wide range of possible research topics from around the world for their final papers. You do not have to be a musician to take this class. You just have to be willing to open your ears, listen, read, and think.
Required texts: Materials online; & Kate Turabian, A Manual for Writers of Research Papers, Theses, and Dissertations, 9th Ed. ISBN-10: 022643057X and ISBN-13: 978-0226430577 
Grading structure: Class discussion, shorts presentations, lead-in assignments to the History Department's writing-requirement research paper.  
Fulfills the following History Concentrations: "Women, Gender, and Sexuality" "Law, Economics and Human Rights," "Empires, Nations, and Citizenship," "United States History before and after 1860," "European History after 1750," & "General Studies in History."
course_description:
Jr/Sr Colloquium. 
This course is an interdisciplinary exploration of the connections between music and politics since 1750. Students will write independent research papers on topics of their choosing, using professional formats, strong evidence, and polished prose.
